text: If you've heard that rumour it is worth checking with someone closer to the university system than me - I was just basing my answer on how I remember the experience 10-15 years ago!

Average debt will vary, not necessarily between courses, but between institutions. Not all universities are charging the full rate that they are allowed, and obviously if you do a 4 year course it will leave you with more debt than a 3 year course. Debt levels are getting pretty high though - I'm sure you've seen lots of discussions about it in the news. Is it something that worries you?
Mhm I did go on a open day to a university today and asked this question. They say that the rumor isnt true but if you do get your application in early - it is beneficial :)
Nah, university loans dont worry me too much.. But of-course the thought of being in debt at a young age does worry me a little bit.
Do law firms have a preference towards candiates who have a law degree or a degree that is convertable?
Or are they both looked at equally?
Which candidate (law or convertable degree) may have a higher chance to be accepted by law firms?
